title: ‘We forgive, but never forget’: yes campaigner Rachel Perkins responds to Warren Mundine on Uluru statement
description: The Kalkadoon and Arrernte filmmaker speaks to Full Story podcast after prominent voice opponent labelled statement a ‘symbolic declaration of war’  Voice referendum explainer; latest voice poll results; help us monitor ads and misinformation Get our morning and afternoon news emails, free app or daily news podcast
contributors: Laura Murphy-Oates

title: What is Daniel Andrews’ legacy?
description: Labor’s longest-serving Victorian premier has resigned. ‘When it is time, it is time,’ he said at a snap press conference held on Tuesday.So what now for Dan Andrews?Benita Kolovos, the Victorian correspondent for Guardian Australia, speaks to Jane Lee
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Benita Kolovos. Produced by Daniel Semo and Joe Koning who also did sound design and mix. Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: Hoot hoot for the powerful owl
description: It is Australia’s largest owl and can be found in urban forests in Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane, where it’s at risk from cars, power lines and common household pesticides. As the Australian bird of the year poll kicks off, Jane Lee goes in search of a powerful owl with nature writer Harry Saddler and Birdlife Australia’s Sean Dooley
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Sean Dooley and Harry Saddler.  Produced, sound design and mixing  byCamilla Hannan. Executive producer  Gabrielle Jackson

title: The Murdoch succession
description: Last week, Rupert Murdoch announced that he was stepping down as the chairman of Fox and News Corp and that his son Lachlan would be taking the reins.Anne Davies joins Jane Lee to discuss what we can learn from Lachlan Murdoch’s past business dealings and how his political ideology might shape one of the most powerful media companies in the world
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Anne Davies. Produced by Karishma Luthria and Allison Chan. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Newsroom edition: is the housing crisis finally being taken seriously?
description: Australia’s chronic housing crisis has been decades in the making. And as the scale of the shortage continues to grow, the states are stepping up. Victoria and NSW have recently introduced a suite of reforms aimed at tackling supply, while federally, Labor’s landmark housing policy finally passed the Senate. But after years of stagnation, will these new measures make an impact?Gabrielle Jackson speaks to the Guardian Australia editor-in-chief, Lenore Taylor, and head of newsroom, Mike Ticher, about whether small steps can make a big difference in the housing crisis
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. Executive producer is Gabrielle Jackson

title: The horrifying allegations against Russell Brand
description: The comedian, presenter and actor has been accused of sexual assault, emotional abuse and rape between 2006 and 2013 – allegations Brand denies. Alexandra Topping explains why such stories can be particularly difficult to investigate
contributors: Presented by Nosheen Iqbal with Alexandra Topping. Produced by Courtney Yusuf, Sami Kent and Rudi Zygadlo. Executive producer Homa Khaleeli. Additional production by Joe Koning

title: Preparing for the worst bushfire season since black summer
description: As an El Niño weather event is declared in Australia, multiple areas of the country are already experiencing soaring temperatures.And authorities are urging communities to prepare for the most significant bushfire season since the black summer fires.Gabrielle Jackson speaks to deputy rural and regional editor Calla Wahlquist about how to prepare for the worst and how she plans to protect her beloved horses
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Calla Wahlquist. Produced by Allison Chan and Karishma Luthria. Sound design and mixing by Joe Koning. Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: The big Australian companies cashing in on healthcare
description: Some of Australia’s largest companies are getting into the business of healthcare, claiming they are making medical appointments and prescriptions easier to access. But not everyone is convinced. Health reporter Natasha May tells Laura Murphy-Oates why some experts are concerned about the rise of ‘McMedicine’  Help make our podcast better by filling out our listener survey: http://theguardian.com/podcastsurveyau
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Natasha May. Produced by Karishma Luthria. Sound design and mixing by Joe Koning. Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: Could your clothes be making you sick?
description: Stain-resistant, wrinkle-proof, hard-wearing – modern clothing can cope with anything. But we know little about the chemicals that go into making it so impressive – or what they could be doing to our health  Help make our podcast better by filling out our listener survey: http://theguardian.com/podcastsurveyau
contributors: Introduced by Gabrielle Jackson. Hosted by Nosheen Iqbal with Alden Wicker. Produced by Eli Block and Holly Chacksfield. Sound design by Rudi Zygadlo. Executive producer Homa Khaleeli. Additional production by Joe Koning and Allison Chan

title: Newsroom edition: is the no campaign’s strategy of division here to stay?
description: A month from voice referendum day, the no campaign’s lead appears to be growing on the back of a strategy of sowing fear and doubt. Jane Lee speaks with editor-in-chief Lenore Taylor and head of newsroom Mike Ticher about how divisive politics are shaping the debate on an Indigenous voice to parliament  Help make our podcast better by filling out our listener survey: http://theguardian.com/podcastsurveyau
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Miles Herbert. Sound design and mixing by James Milsom. Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: Have the Greens lost the fight for renters’ rights?
description: After months of tense negotiations, the Greens have agreed to support Labor’s $10bn housing Australia future fund (Haff) bill.And while the minor party are claiming victory on securing an extra $3bn for community housing, there is nothing additional for renters.Chief political correspondent for Guardian Australia, Paul Karp, tells Jane Lee why the Greens did a deal with Labor and how they are still chasing renters’ votes
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Paul Karp produced by Daniel Semo who also did the SD and mix. Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: The voice AMA: yes and no campaigners on ‘division’ and ‘dirty tactics’
description: With referendum day just over a month away, polling for the yes campaign continues to slide despite an advertising push. In this episode of the Full Story series The voice ask me anything, we speak to leading Indigenous voices from the yes and no campaigns about ‘dirty tactics’, Peter Dutton’s proposal for a second referendum and whether the voice to parliament could help close the gap.Laura Murphy-Oates is joined by no campaigner senator Kerrynne Liddle from the Liberal party and yes campaigner Tanya Hosch
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Allison Chan, Phoebe McIlwraith and Camilla Hannan who also did the sound design and mix. Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: The secret graves of the Stolen Generations
description: Multiple sites of possible secret burials have been discovered on the grounds of one of the most violent and abusive institutions of the Stolen Generations era.Indigenous affairs editor Lorena Allam and Indigenous affairs reporter Sarah Collard speak to Laura Murphy-Oates about how they broke the story and why survivors are calling for an urgent investigation into the possible clandestine graves
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Lorena Allam and Sarah Collard. Produced by Karishma Luthria, Laura Murphy-Oates and Daniel Semo who also did the sound design and mixing. Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: The chilling rise of AI scams
description: Criminals are cloning voices and making calls to trick victims into sending them money. How can they be stopped?
contributors: Introduced by Jane Lee. Presented by Michael Safi with Oliver Devane. Produced by Eli Block, Tom Glasser and Rudi Zygadlo; executive producer is Homa Khaleeli. Additional production by Mell Chun

title: Newsroom edition: why competition is key to cleaning up Qantas’s mess
description: Despite record profits, Australia’s biggest airline continues to anger its customers. As complaints roll in, competition watchdog the ACCC has warned the aviation industry is at a ‘critical juncture’ and poor policy has created a duopoly leaving passengers with high ticket prices and poor service.Jane Lee talks to editor-in-chief Lenore Taylor and head of news Mike Ticher about competition and how the government could help bring air fares back down
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Miles Herbert and James Milsom. The executive producer is Molly Glassey

title: Why top execs are leaving the mining company with a ‘green vision’
description: In the week following its star-studded 20th birthday celebration, iron ore giant Fortescue has seen three high-profile resignations.Fortescue’s founder Andrew Forrest has cited differences in vision for the company, but neither CEO Fiona Hick, CFO Christine Morris nor director Guy Debelle have spoken publicly about the reason for their resignations.One thing we do know is that shareholders are uncomfortable.Are these resignations really down to employees not sharing Fortescue’s ‘green vision’? Or does the company have a governance problem? Guardian Australia’s senior business reporter Jonathan Barrett speaks to Jane Lee
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Jonathan Barrett produced by Allison Chan and Mell Chun Sound design and mix by Joe Koning Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: Can Alan Joyce’s departure save Qantas?
description: Alan Joyce’s reign as the boss of Qantas has come to an end.The divisive CEO announced his shock early retirement after 15 years in the role and a turbulent week for the airline as it prepares to fight a war on many fronts, including a consumer watchdog lawsuit and a possible Senate inquiry.Transport and urban affairs reporter Elias Visontay tells Laura Murphy-Oates whether Joyce’s departure can save the airline’s reputation and what it means for the future of what was once one of Australia’s most-loved companies
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Elias Visontay produced by Phoebe McIlwraith and Daniel Semo  who also did the sound design and mixing. Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: Why wasn’t Lucy Letby stopped sooner?
description: The nurse is the most prolific child serial killer in modern British history. Could the NHS have prevented her committing so many crimes?
contributors: Presented by Nosheen Iqbal with Josh Halliday; produced by Hannah Moore, Lucy Hough, and Rudi Zygadlo; executive producer Elizabeth Cassin; additional production by Joe Koning

title: Labor’s new rules for the gig economy
description: The government’s long-awaited plan to protect gig economy workers comes before parliament this week. Under the bill, the Fair Work Commission will be given the power to set minimum standards for hundreds of thousands of ‘employee-like workers’ on digital platforms such as Uber and Hungry Panda.Chief political correspondent Paul Karp tells Jane Lee whether the proposed reforms go far enough to keep workers safe
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Paul Karp produced by Karishma Luthria with sound design and mixing by Joe Koning Executive producer Hannah Parkes

title: Indigenous voice referendum AMA: the government already has advice, how does the voice differ?
description: Many people throughout the referendum debate have questioned the need for a voice to parliament when the government can already receive advice on Indigenous affairs. Guardian Australia’s political reporter Josh Butler explains that while the government does have access to advice there “aren't bodies that exist like this in the same way that the voice is envisioned” and constitutional empowerment is the key functional difference.  ► Subscribe to Guardian Australia on YouTube   The yes pamphlet: campaign’s voice to parliament referendum essay – annotated and factchecked  The no pamphlet: campaign’s voice to parliament referendum essay – annotated and factchecked  Check out our voice explainer and the latest voice poll results
contributors: Laura Murphy-Oates Josh Butler
